question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for establishing native forbs in a degraded grassland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies on establishing native forbs and grassland species: sowing native grass and forb seeds increased forb species richness in 71% of cases and increased forb cover or density in most cases examined [3432]. Sowing at a higher seed density increased forb species richness and cover in replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies [3405]. Planting grassland plants increased forb species richness in 83% of cases, and adding plantings to seeding increased total and native species compared to seeding alone [3399]. Disturbing soil before seeding increased forb species richness in most cases compared to harrowing and increased forb cover in a replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study [3413]. Irrigating after sowing native seeds did not alter plant species richness in one replicated, controlled study [3430]. Using an organic erosion blanket after sowing increased overall plant species richness in one study [3431]. Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding had mixed effects: it did not change overall richness in one study, did not alter biomass of three native grass and forb species in another, but increased the abundance of some target species in one study [3429].
summary_statements: Sowing native grass and forb seeds increased forb species richness in 71% of cases.
Sowing native grass and forb seeds increased forb cover or density in most cases examined.
Sowing at a higher seed density increased forb species richness.
Sowing at a higher seed density increased forb cover in replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies.
Planting grassland plants increased forb species richness in 83% of cases.
Adding plantings to seeding increased total and native species compared to seeding alone.
Disturbing soil before seeding increased forb species richness in most cases compared to harrowing.
Disturbing soil before seeding increased forb cover in a replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study.
Irrigating after sowing native seeds did not alter plant species richness in one replicated, controlled study.
Using an organic erosion blanket after sowing increased overall plant species richness in one study.
Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding had mixed effects.
Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding did not change overall richness in one study.
Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding did not alter the biomass of three native grass and forb species in another study.
Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding increased the abundance of some target species in one study.

question_details.query: How does sowing native grass and forb seeds impact local pollinator populations?
What are the effects of burning vegetation before planting on grassland species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies have evaluated the effects of burning vegetation before seeding/planting on grassland vegetation, so the effects on grassland species richness are not assessed [3417].
summary_statements: No studies have evaluated the effects of burning vegetation before seeding or planting on grassland vegetation.
The effects of burning vegetation before planting on grassland species richness are not assessed.

question_details.query: Is adding fertilizer more effective for increasing overall vegetation cover than inoculating soil with mycorrhiza after seeding?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Adding fertilizer alongside seeding/planting: Six of nine replicated, controlled studies reported increases in vegetation cover in all or some cases, while three studies found no change [3427]. In peatlands planted with peatland species, fertilizer increased total vegetation, vascular plant and bryophyte cover in one Canadian bog; in another Canadian bog restored as a fen it increased sedge cover but did not affect total vegetation cover, total herb cover or Sphagnum cover; a New Zealand bog reported increased cover of a sown shrub and a rush depending on fertilizer chemical and peat preparation [1826]. Adding inorganic fertilizer without planting increased total vegetation cover in a New Zealand bog [1812].
- Inoculating soil with mycorrhiza around seeding/planting: Before sowing, one replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study found vegetation cover initially increased but after three years did not differ from uninoculated areas; another controlled study found adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change overall herbaceous cover [3429]. There is no evidence assessing the effects of infecting tree seedlings with mycorrhizae [1160].
summary_statements: Six of nine replicated, controlled studies reported that adding fertilizer alongside seeding or planting increased vegetation cover in all or some cases.
Three of nine replicated, controlled studies found that adding fertilizer alongside seeding or planting resulted in no change to vegetation cover.
In peatlands planted with peatland species, fertilizer increased total vegetation, vascular plant and bryophyte cover in one Canadian bog.
In another Canadian bog restored as a fen, adding fertilizer increased sedge cover but did not affect total vegetation cover, total herb cover or Sphagnum cover.
A New Zealand bog reported increased cover of a sown shrub and a rush depending on the fertilizer chemical and peat preparation.
Adding inorganic fertilizer without planting increased total vegetation cover in a New Zealand bog.
One study on inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before sowing found that vegetation cover initially increased.
One study on inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before sowing found that after three years, vegetation cover did not differ from uninoculated areas.
A controlled study found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change overall herbaceous cover.
There is no evidence assessing the effects of infecting tree seedlings with mycorrhizae.
